author: Lucio Fernandes

text:
Some days after I bought my Switch and this game (in a bundle) I traveled with my dad to the other side of the country in our car trough the mountain side and unfortunatelly (or fortunatelly) the gasoline ran out in a foresty path with big pine trees, like the ones in this level. It was annoying at first, but the escenery was gorgeous and it made me feel good. I was thinking in this track all the time while I was exploring the place (meanwhile we where waiting for someone to help us with gas for the car).
It was a really magic experience jajajaja I always remember it when I hear this track.

text: Surprised to see that you picked this track! author: nessx007

text: I think it's the way it plays after you enter the tunnel and are met with the core level (since you start outside in the forest), but also because it's simply such a feel-good track. You're right that it feels un-mario, but that's also what made it stand out in a refreshing way.

author: ZXKW

text: Now that I recently finished (and 100% completed) this game, let me say this: Super Mario Odyssey is an amazing platformer. As much I loved the Galaxy games and 3D Land/World, playing this game confirmed that I simply prefer the open world 3D Mario games. It's the first game to challenge Mario 64 as my favorite in the 3D series, and I'm tempted to say that this game grabbed the top spot. Perfect gameplay, huge amount of content, perfect balance between new ideas and nostalgia for Mario's roots... superb. I do think there were a lot of challenge levels (the ones behind doors) that could have been directly integrated to the levels' instead of feeling like fluorescent bonus rooms, but I do understand how that would have made the level design even harder to put together. While I feel like Zelda still has a lot of room to improve on the BOTW formula (I predict it will be one of my favorite games ever), I feel like Mario Odyssey already achieved near-perfection.
author: SupraDarky

text: Also, I was pleasantly suprised to learn that this track which was an instant favorite is one of the few composed by the one and only Koji Kondo. He still has it!
author: SupraDarky

text:
This is my favorite track from the game, I never knew it was composed by Koji Kondo!

I'm still disappointed that he left the Zelda series, BotW is my most favorite game to date but the music wasn't good imo...honestly after Wind Waker the quality of the music from Zelda went down, I remember how I was looking forward to the OST of every new Zelda game but now I'm kinda hoping for it to be at least good.
author: Super Fox

text: Super Fox The music in BotW was never meant to steal the show like it does in all the others (which btw, TP and SS have fire soundtracks imo).  You're supposed to feel very alone and like you're hiking through woods irl.  That's a difficult feeling to maintain with a melody present.  Subtle, soft instrumentals were introduced to make things a little more magical, but I'm glad they restrained themselves to just that.  The towns, castle, and bosses have fantastic tracks as the icing on the sound design cake.
author: cinnabon suppository

text:
I honestly appreciate the choice they went with BotW & how minimalistic the OST was in order to convey the feeling of the world, but at the same time I think even the subtle pieces we hear from BotW were weaker than WW & before games.

I also think that TP & SS had much weaker OSTs in general with very few standouts, but OoT, MM, WW, ALttP...are infinitely better imo :)
author: Super Fox

text: I also enjoy the game, but I have a real problem with all the repeated filler stars you can collect. The tasks you have to do are always the same and rarely challenging or interesting.
author: Marloges P

text: This soundtrack is full of great tunes!
author: Philip J. Fry II

text: I didn't know that this track was composed by Koji Kondo. I seriously thinks it's one of the best from the soundtrack! There's a reason why he's my all time favorite video game composer.
author: Eirian Odalis

text: And yes, this game is extremely good. It basically doesn't have any flaws, and if it has, they are all small ones. I can easily see myself looking back at this game in ten years and remembering all the time I spent playing it.  Beautiful stuff!
author: Eirian Odalis

text: @SupraDarky Koji is definitely one of Nintendo's lifebloods. What I mean in that is Nintendo wouldn't be where they are today without at least a little bit of that Koji Kondo magic.
